title: Arches/SPENS: The context
segmentation: So I'll start off with with with the introducing Bill Burton.
I'll finalize the European Commission side and supporting or managing both projects for a number of years.
I think that I want to add on some of the first projects and that's that's lost back in history.
Sorry, this project Springs to mind and various other ones where rivers been heavily involved in the family supportive.
And I would stress that word, and I think Alex was already talked about that normally when you see a European Commission funding project, it says at the bottom supported by the European Commission.
I think for Archers and spends that really means something.
As Alycia said, the European Commission right from Riverie initiation has been very, very supportive of these activities.
Encouraging guiding, bullying, pushing or whatever to get these projects off the ground to make sure that we start to integrate all of their particular new Member States.
But it was just a case of getting into some projects.
New Member States to keep people happy.
It really wants to get together projects which integrate the new Member States with the more established institutes.
So I think that was stuck as a good start.
So with that I want to introduce Bill Bill Byrne from European Commission unit, H2 surface transport and filters.
Thanks Steve.
I I like this emphasis on being heavily involved.
I have lost a few kilos over the last few months, but it's still there.
My presence is is physical as well as mental.
It's a pleasure for me to be here.
In fact.
I mean, I'm really pleased to be here because in principle my director.
So that's my bosses.
Boss Andrew Ziegler was invited to be at the event, but unfortunately he's not being able to attend.
So you have me and you actually get a double helping because I have to speak tomorrow as well.
Um?

Steve is actually quite right in terms of the fact that we are very keen and have always been interested in ensuring that we we support strong and effective research, particularly in Rd infrastructure infrastructure.
I mean my my beginnings and the sort of transition that I had to be involved in.
Rd infrastructure projects came from the fact that my ascential potted CV history is that I come from the railway industry and I spent 2530 years working within the railway sector.
Both in the UK, then also internationally in the Netherlands, and now for the last full five years within the Commission and now onto the road sector.
Original was involved in silence, which was split between the two sectors, and that's where the.

Connection first came with several people in the audience here and and others to be and to realize the involvement in the heavy involvement and naturally the important role that's played by Rd infrastructure in terms of delivering sustainability.
Now what I'm going to do and I'll try to be very brief about this, is to give an idea about the context which in which starches and Spence were actually created.
I mean, you've seen it from the national needs and from the perspective.

Of the EU 12 so I now have to say, and this is a little bit coming in the other direction from the policy stairs, so I talk about the policy and a little bit later we'll hear the nitty gritty of how those projects have worked, what they've achieved, and from my impressions in my involvement on the outside from these projects, I think we should be justifiably proud.
And I hope to say that by the end of the two days of this event you will realize how much is being achieved.
Within these projects, so I'm looking forward with enthusiasm to the rest of the sessions, but you'll have to look forward to my speech just refused.
Chickens as well.
OK, let's put this into context.
Steve's already mentioned that I work for the unit which is dealing with sustainable transport.

This little buggy thing in the background is not necessarily the Commission's view of sustainable transport in the future, but it helps to illustrate the idea, which is one of the guiding principles for us.
And actually it is one of the main.
Efforts that we actually strike to to achieve.

I talk for a long time so that you can actually read the text, but the most fundamental aspect of sustainable mobility is to actually ensure that we still keep freedom of movement, which is an element which could be under jeopardy in terms of the green environment.
In the green perspective, but also ensuring that the economy is sustained and making sure that the social impact of our demands for future use in future mobility.
Are not actually eroded.
Now that's words.
Prefer pictures and I have to make it fairly local, so that's bled.
Within sustainability you have the three crucial areas we normally we talk about pillars within the Commission.
But here we talk about.
They are circles here on here.

They look like... but at least on the screen as circles and you have the three different elements of the social aspects, the environmental aspects and economic aspects and to to really ensure that you have sustainability.
The three dimensions themselves must be actually treated equally.
You have this concept of an equilateral triangle.
The fact that if you actually move too far to have economic pressures, or if you make the sense of the environment too strong.
It actually distorts that triangle and you lose the effect of sustainability.
So is it as a quick and easy way of looking at sustainability and the elements that are involved?
This is a perfect example.
There's another way of thinking about it in terms of people and profit and the perspectives as well.
But this is the.
It is the most simple way of thinking of sustainability.
Now coming from the Commission, I have to have a picture of the Commission building in it.
Otherwise they don't pay for my travel costs.
So there is the benamor building in the background.
I wanted to explain a little bit about the Lisbon Strategy, which was the perspective that came around in order to stimulate the European economy.
OK, at the moment and in a time of crisis, which is debatable, whether it still is a crisis or not, but I'm sure it's not over yet.
There has to be an understanding of what we need to deliver.
To ensure European competitiveness but at the same time and overall growth in terms of the economy and in terms of knowledge.
And you will see a different triangle again.
But in order to ensure both growth and focus on jobs, there has to be a combination.
Looking at research, looking at innovation and education.
So this is a strong steer.
However, it was realized that if you go too far in that direction, you begin to distort the triangle.
So at Gothenburg buses back in 1991.
But it's still relevant now.
The perspective was there to say we need to ensure that sustainability is taken into account, so it's fine to have economic growth and development, but it mustn't be lossed.
With respect to the environmental perspective.
And there it is.

Highlighted very strongly that transport was an area which is fundamental where extra work has to be taken to ensure that there is a strong emphasis on environmental friendliness and when we talk about this tomorrow, you'll see that one of the strong areas of work that we as the Commissioner sponsoring now in relation to the what we call the recovery package in terms of the European economy, is this aspect of Greening of green cars and electrification, but more about that.
Tomorrow.

Another element that creeps into this also is you have the economic aspect you have the environmental aspect, but also there is the one of transport policy and ensuring that we are able to keep track of the demand that there is for transport.
How do we actually make the transportation system within Europe work effectively?
What do we do about congestion?
How do we ensure that we get the best from the transport networks that we have available and.
Every 10 years, the Commission does a review of its transport policy every five years.
Within those 10 years, it reviews the review and the whole idea of this is to try to make sure that we look at the moving perspectives within Europe.
I mean, obviously since 2004 we now have EU 10.
We now have you 12 and the the whole focus of Europe has changed.
The perspective is now moving East and we have to make sure that we have the right network in place.
In order to get the effective movement that will sustain the economy.
So.
So the transport perspective is one that is very critical from the side of DG Research.
Obviously our focus is on research policy and within the different framework programs that we have, we looked to support areas of research which will help meet the policy.
The factors that we that we need to control or need to be taking into consideration, but also ensuring that we create the right environment for that research to take place.
More of this tomorrow about making sure that the economic circumstances are right, that the technical environments are right as well.
But in the context of Archers and Spence, they were funded under our 6th Framework Programme, which is now in effect coming to an end.
These two projects are some of the last ones that were sponsored in the Sixth Framework Programme and within that Framework Program and certainly for surface transport.
There was an area that was recognized for work which related to sustainable development.
And global change.

And if you see down into the the lowest category there, you have sustainable transport systems and then two different areas where we see that there is definite work that has to be done to support transport either in terms of the environmentally friendly aspects or actually making sure that the transport we deliver is not only safer and effective, but also it provides competition in terms of supporting the transport manufacturing industry that we have.
So you can see where we're trying to juggle with about.
16 bulls at the same time and from time to try and be dropped.
But that's another story.
OK, this is the slide that's been put into catch me out because it has an animation on it.

So let's let's get it going so that I can follow it through one of those two areas that you notice before about surface transport was looking at ensuring and delivering environmentally friendly transport systems, and one of the two subsectors that were looked at and considered within.
There was one on advanced design and production tech.
Allergies.
There were specific objectives that were identified in that area.
Looking at product quality, looking at recycling some of the other projects that I have that are involved in recycling techniques.
How do we get more effective operations and what do we do in terms of delivering a more environmentally friendly transport?
System.
So the focus of this work was actually to look specifically at process is related to surface transport.

To see what we needed to do in terms of either serious production or customization, and also, how do we develop new techniques to deliver a more competitive and a more cost effective transport system?
For the future.
Not in particular.

In the third call of F B6, which was in 2005, there was one area of research that we had identified which was the one that was targeted by Spence and Archers, so you can see we're coming down from the overall policy objectives from this aspect of sustainability.
From what we need to do in transport policy, how we need to be effective for the environment through into the 6th Framework Programme and now dovetailing it even more.
Into the demands that we identified within the third call of the Six Framework Program.

And here it looks at new construction concepts for Rd infrastructure, making sure that it's high quality, cost effective, energy efficient and that is looking specifically at rapid infrastructure renewal.

And you'll see at the end that that extra sentence, which is the one that in effect Steve was talking about in terms of the will of the Commission to be embracing of the of the research resource that there is within Central Eastern Europe to have special consideration for the demands of the new Member States.
So that was very much in our mind when we put to.
Yeah, that topic for research.
You will see that this is the participation by country during the FP6 for all the surface transport projects.
Large piece of the pie as it stands at the moment was for the EU 15.
I mean these are people that are well versed in transport research, but slowly the pious is changing it in blue you see the areas where the new Member States are coming in.
In Green is a little slice for the international cooperation and the idea was to stimulate the enlargement of the of the blue sector within the cake.
So that was in terms of percentage of participation of.
Partners within all the projects that we did.

But here you can get a feel for what's happening in terms of the development of that of the money that was paid to the different Member States in relation to the to the framework program to the 6th Framework Programme.
And there you will see it the healthy growth in Core 2B and call 3B whether the proportion of the new Member State funding is actually increasing.
So when you go on the little walk a bit later on, you'll come to the triple bridge within Lubiana.

The whole idea here was to give you the the background of why we were very, very motivated to support the projects that radishes already described what we were doing in terms of Archer Spence and certain, we really saw that there was a need that was clearly identified to us in terms of concentrating on new Member State issues, and we recognize that because it was at the very very beginning of of new Member State involvement in Framework program projects.
Vert they had to be brought in and encouraged to learn the sort of rules of the game so.
What better than by doing it through a practical means?
The idea is obviously, and what is actually being achieved, and you'll see that over the next two days is to have positive and effective results, and also to stimulate participation.
So that's a lot.
A bit about the backgrounds and now I leave the stage open to some more clarification about the different projects themselves.
Thanks, Steve.
